title: Why are there no new classic Christmas songs? They all seem to have been written back in the day. - Quora

response.answer_text: From what I’ve observed, at some point some 20 years ago, they stopped playing the old standard Christmas carols in shopping malls and other commercial venues, in favor of secular Christmas songs. I can understand why they did this—-not every customer is a Christian, and some might not care to hear “Silent Night” or “Hark, The Herald Angels Sing” if their interest in the Christmas and New Year’s holidays is purely secular. Yet playing Christmas music from the day after Thanksgiving until the store closes late Christmas eve is considered a dandy way to get customers into a spending mood, so they needed replacements for these old carols. So they started digging around for secular holiday songs, because when they subtracted all the religious songs there wasn’t much left—-just “Jingle Bells” and “Silver Bells” and “Walkin’ In A Winter Wonderland.” What they found were a lot of vaguely Christmas related songs from the fifties and forties, usually about relaxing in front of the fireplace with a hot toddy, or enjoying a beautiful snowfall. They also recycled a lot of songs that had been strictly little children’s songs back in the day—-”Frosty the Snowman” and “Rudolph The Red-Nosed Reindeer,” for example. So songs that hadn’t been all that popular for the past 30 years suddenly made a comeback: “Baby, It’s Cold Outside,” “It’s Beginning To Look A Lot Like Christmas,” “Santa, Baby,” “Sleigh Ride” (both the original orchestral piece and a tacky sung version), “I’ll Be Home For Christmas” (a favorite WWII song), the Beach Boys’ entire Christmas album,” and “Jingle Bell Rock.” Musicians are still coming up with new Christmas songs, because, if they catch on, there’s a good chance that they’ll become classics; but they’ve also found that performing the same old standards can be lucrative. So we have 9000 versions of “Chestnuts Roasting On An Open Fire” and “White Christmas”—-and the public never seems to tire of them.

You could try a British hit from December 2008. It was a charity single (raising money for the NSPCC) co-written and sung by Peter Kay, using the persona of a character he had created a year earlier for “Britain's Got the Pop Factor... and Possibly a New Celebrity Jesus Christ Soapstar Superstar Strictly on Ice” a comedy series which spoofed the “factor/got talent” shows which have been infesting the UK Christmas charts for the last thirty years. Kay’s character “Geraldine McQueen” released “Winner’s Song” in 2007 and we all assumed that he would move on to a new idea (he did two years later with “The Tour That Doesn't Tour Tour...Now On Tour”) but it turned out that Peter really did have a bee in his bonnet about those talent shows dominating the charts every Christmas and decided to try and do something about it. First a caveat. If you haven’t already played the link. You will almost certainly find yourself singing it “over and over and over again” if you do. The result was  “Once Upon A Christmas Song”. It somehow parodies the Christmas hits of the past and acts as a good “Christmas Song” at the same time, possibly because Peter really does love those old songs. Unfortunately it only reached No5 in our charts. The No1 spot being taken by one of those “show winner’s” songs, Alexandra Burke’s version of “Hallelujah”.
